sn36.18:1.1.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu …pe…
sn36.18:1.1.eng: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha …

sn36.18:1.2.pli: ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavā etadavoca:

sn36.18:1.3.pli: “katamā nu kho, bhikkhave, vedanā, katamo vedanāsamudayo, katamo vedanānirodho, katamā vedanānirodhagāminī paṭipadā?
sn36.18:1.3.eng: “Mendicants, what is feeling? What’s the origin of feeling? What’s the cessation of feeling? What’s the practice that leads to the cessation of feeling?

sn36.18:1.4.pli: Ko vedanāya assādo, ko ādīnavo, kiṃ nissaraṇan”ti?
sn36.18:1.4.eng: And what is feeling’s gratification, drawback, and escape?”

sn36.18:1.5.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”

sn36.18:1.7.pli: sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā—

sn36.18:1.9.eng: (Tell in full as in the previous discourse.)

sn36.19:1.1.pli: Atha kho pañcakaṅgo thapati yenāyasmā udāyī tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ udāyiṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho pañcakaṅgo thapati āyasmantaṃ udāyiṃ etadavoca:
sn36.19:1.1.eng: Then the chamberlain Pañcakaṅga went up to Venerable Udāyī, bowed, sat down to one side, and asked him,
sn36.19:1.1.comm: This discourse is also at MN 59, where it is called “Many Feelings”. | Pañcakaṅga features as a prominent devotee of the Buddha in MN 78, MN 127, and in a parallel to the current sutta at MN 59. As thapati (“chamberlain”) he was the ranking official under Pasenadi. Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 5.4.4.17–18 tells us that royal authority goes from the king, to the king’s brother, to the thapati, to the village head. Similarly, Atharva Veda 2.32.4a and 5.23.11a mention the thapati directly after the king. SN 55.6:15.1 shows the thapati was trusted with the most intimate and sensitive duties of the court. Elsewhere we learn that they shared the meal and carriage with the king, accompanying him on military campaigns (MN 89:18.1), while SN 55.6:1.4 shows them engaged in governing the provinces. Thus the thapati was the highest non-royal official in the court, entrusted with governing, advising, and security of the household. | There are several individuals called Udāyī, and it is not possible to distinguish them all.

sn36.19:1.2.pli: “kati nu kho, bhante udāyi, vedanā vuttā bhagavatā”ti?
sn36.19:1.2.eng: “Sir, how many feelings has the Buddha spoken of?”

sn36.19:1.3.eng: “Chamberlain, the Buddha has spoken of three feelings:

sn36.19:1.4.pli: Sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā—

sn36.19:1.5.pli: imā kho, thapati, tisso vedanā vuttā bhagavatā”ti.
sn36.19:1.5.eng: The Buddha has spoken of these three feelings.”

sn36.19:1.6.pli: Evaṃ vutte, pañcakaṅgo thapati āyasmantaṃ udāyiṃ etadavoca:
sn36.19:1.6.eng: When he said this, Pañcakaṅga said to Udāyī,

sn36.19:1.7.pli: “na kho, bhante udāyi, tisso vedanā vuttā bhagavatā.
sn36.19:1.7.eng: “Sir, Udāyī, the Buddha hasn’t spoken of three feelings.

sn36.19:1.10.pli: Yāyaṃ, bhante, adukkhamasukhā vedanā, santasmiṃ esā paṇīte sukhe vuttā bhagavatā”ti.
sn36.19:1.10.eng: The Buddha said that neutral feeling is included as a peaceful and subtle kind of pleasure.”

sn36.19:2.1.pli: Dutiyampi kho āyasmā udāyī pañcakaṅgaṃ thapatiṃ etadavoca:
sn36.19:2.1.eng: For a second time, Udāyī said to him,

sn36.19:2.2.pli: “na kho, thapati, dve vedanā vuttā bhagavatā.
sn36.19:2.2.eng: “The Buddha hasn’t spoken of two feelings,

sn36.19:2.4.pli: Sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā—

sn36.19:2.6.pli: Dutiyampi kho pañcakaṅgo thapati āyasmantaṃ udāyiṃ etadavoca:
sn36.19:2.6.eng: For a second time, Pañcakaṅga said to Udāyī,

sn36.19:2.7.pli: “na kho, bhante udāyi, tisso vedanā vuttā bhagavatā.
sn36.19:2.7.eng: “The Buddha hasn’t spoken of three feelings,

sn36.19:2.10.pli: Yāyaṃ, bhante, adukkhamasukhā vedanā, santasmiṃ esā paṇīte sukhe vuttā bhagavatā”ti.

sn36.19:3.1.pli: Tatiyampi kho āyasmā udāyī pañcakaṅgaṃ thapatiṃ etadavoca:
sn36.19:3.1.eng: And for a third time, Udāyī said to him,

sn36.19:3.2.pli: “na kho, thapati, dve vedanā vuttā bhagavatā.
sn36.19:3.2.eng: “The Buddha hasn’t spoken of two feelings,

sn36.19:3.4.pli: Sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā—

sn36.19:3.6.pli: Tatiyampi kho pañcakaṅgo thapati āyasmantaṃ udāyiṃ etadavoca:
sn36.19:3.6.eng: And for a third time, Pañcakaṅga said to Udāyī,

sn36.19:3.7.pli: “na kho, bhante udāyi, tisso vedanā vuttā bhagavatā.
sn36.19:3.7.eng: “The Buddha hasn’t spoken of three feelings,

sn36.19:3.10.pli: Yāyaṃ, bhante, adukkhamasukhā vedanā, santasmiṃ esā paṇīte sukhe vuttā bhagavatā”ti.

sn36.19:3.11.pli: Neva sakkhi āyasmā udāyī pañcakaṅgaṃ thapatiṃ saññāpetuṃ, na panāsakkhi pañcakaṅgo thapati āyasmantaṃ udāyiṃ saññāpetuṃ.
sn36.19:3.11.eng: But neither was able to persuade the other.

sn36.19:3.12.pli: Assosi kho āyasmā ānando āyasmato udāyissa pañcakaṅgena thapatinā saddhiṃ imaṃ kathāsallāpaṃ.
sn36.19:3.12.eng: Venerable Ānanda heard this discussion between Udāyī and Pañcakaṅga.

sn36.19:4.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
sn36.19:4.1.eng: He went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side,
sn36.19:4.1.comm: The parallel passage at MN 59:4.2 includes abhivādetvā (“bowed”), which is missing here. In such cases translation requires judgment: should we read this as a deliberate elision meant to be filled in; or is it a mistake in the text that should be reflected in the translation?

sn36.19:4.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando yāvatako āyasmato udāyissa pañcakaṅgena thapatinā saddhiṃ ahosi kathāsallāpo taṃ sabbaṃ bhagavato ārocesi.
sn36.19:4.2.eng: and informed the Buddha of all they had discussed.

sn36.19:5.1.pli: “Santameva, ānanda, pariyāyaṃ pañcakaṅgo thapati udāyissa bhikkhuno nābbhanumodi;
sn36.19:5.1.eng: “Ānanda, the explanation by the mendicant Udāyī, which the chamberlain Pañcakaṅga didn’t agree with, was quite correct.

sn36.19:5.2.pli: santañca panānanda, pariyāyaṃ udāyī bhikkhu pañcakaṅgassa thapatino nābbhanumodi.
sn36.19:5.2.eng: But the explanation by Pañcakaṅga, which Udāyī didn’t agree with, was also quite correct.

sn36.19:5.3.pli: Dvepi mayā, ānanda, vedanā vuttā pariyāyena.
sn36.19:5.3.eng: In one explanation I’ve spoken of two feelings. In another explanation I’ve spoken of three feelings, or five, six, eighteen, thirty-six, or a hundred and eight feelings.
sn36.19:5.3.comm: These are all explained in SN 36.22.

sn36.19:5.10.pli: Evaṃ pariyāyadesito kho, ānanda, mayā dhammo.
sn36.19:5.10.eng: I’ve explained the teaching in all these different ways.

sn36.19:5.11.pli: Evaṃ pariyāyadesite kho, ānanda, mayā dhamme ye aññamaññassa subhāsitaṃ sulapitaṃ, na samanumaññissanti, na samanujānissanti, na samanumodissanti, tesaṃ etaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ—bhaṇḍanajātā kalahajātā vivādāpannā aññamaññaṃ mukhasattīhi vitudantā viharissantīti.
sn36.19:5.11.eng: This being so, you can expect that those who don’t concede, approve, or agree with what has been well spoken will fight, quarrel, and dispute, continually wounding each other with barbed words.

sn36.19:5.12.pli: Evaṃ pariyāyadesito kho, ānanda, mayā dhammo.
sn36.19:5.12.eng: I’ve explained the teaching in all these different ways.

sn36.19:5.13.pli: Evaṃ pariyāyadesite kho, ānanda, mayā dhamme ye aññamaññassa subhāsitaṃ sulapitaṃ samanumaññissanti samanujānissanti samanumodissanti, tesaṃ etaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ—samaggā sammodamānā avivadamānā khīrodakībhūtā aññamaññaṃ piyacakkhūhi sampassantā viharissantīti.
sn36.19:5.13.eng: This being so, you can expect that those who do concede, approve, or agree with what has been well spoken will live in harmony, appreciating each other, without dispute, blending like milk and water, and regarding each other with kindly eyes.

sn36.19:6.1.eng: There are these five kinds of sensual stimulation.

sn36.19:6.3.pli: Cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā …pe…
sn36.19:6.3.eng: Sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing. …

sn36.19:6.4.pli: kāyaviññeyyā phoṭṭhabbā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn36.19:6.4.eng: Touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn36.19:6.5.eng: These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

sn36.19:6.6.pli: Yaṃ kho, ānanda, ime pañca kāmaguṇe paṭicca uppajjati sukhaṃ somanassaṃ—
sn36.19:6.6.eng: The pleasure and happiness that arise from these five kinds of sensual stimulation is called sensual pleasure.

sn36.19:6.8.eng: There are those who might say

sn36.19:6.9.eng: that this is the highest pleasure and happiness that sentient beings experience.
sn36.19:6.9.comm: The PTS reads sattā against MS santaṁ; MS also has sattā at MN 59:7.1. The verb “experiences” requires a plural subject, which in this discourse might be the putative speakers. However, in MN 59 the putative speaker is singular, so the subject must be “sentient beings”.

sn36.19:6.10.eng: But I don’t grant them that.

sn36.19:6.12.pli: Atthānanda, etamhā sukhā aññaṃ sukhaṃ abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca.
sn36.19:6.12.eng: Because there is another pleasure that is finer than that.
sn36.19:6.12.comm: In discussing the path, the Buddha focuses on pleasure.

sn36.19:7.1.pli: Katamañcānanda, etamhā sukhā aññaṃ sukhaṃ abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca?

sn36.19:7.2.pli: Idhānanda, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
sn36.19:7.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

sn36.19:7.3.pli: Idaṃ kho, ānanda, etamhā sukhā aññaṃ sukhaṃ abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca.
sn36.19:7.3.eng: This is a pleasure that is finer than that.

sn36.19:7.4.eng: There are those who might say

sn36.19:7.5.eng: that this is the highest pleasure and happiness that sentient beings experience.

sn36.19:7.6.eng: But I don’t grant them that.

sn36.19:7.8.pli: Atthānanda, etamhā sukhā aññaṃ sukhaṃ abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca.
sn36.19:7.8.eng: Because there is another pleasure that is finer than that.

sn36.19:8.1.pli: Katamañcānanda, etamhā sukhā aññaṃ sukhaṃ abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca?

sn36.19:8.2.pli: Idhānanda, bhikkhu, vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
sn36.19:8.2.eng: It’s when, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.

sn36.19:8.3.pli: Idaṃ kho, ānanda, etamhā sukhā aññaṃ sukhaṃ abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca.
sn36.19:8.3.eng: This is a pleasure that is finer than that.

sn36.19:8.4.eng: There are those who might say

sn36.19:8.5.eng: that this is the highest pleasure and happiness that sentient beings experience.

sn36.19:8.6.eng: But I don’t grant them that.

sn36.19:8.8.pli: Atthānanda, etamhā sukhā aññaṃ sukhaṃ abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca.
sn36.19:8.8.eng: Because there is another pleasure that is finer than that.

sn36.19:9.1.pli: Katamañcānanda, etamhā sukhā aññaṃ sukhaṃ abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca?

sn36.19:9.2.pli: Idhānanda, bhikkhu pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati sato ca sampajāno, sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedeti, yaṃ taṃ ariyā ācikkhanti: ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
sn36.19:9.2.eng: It’s when, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’

sn36.19:9.3.pli: Idaṃ kho, ānanda, etamhā sukhā aññaṃ sukhaṃ abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca.
sn36.19:9.3.eng: This is a pleasure that is finer than that.

sn36.19:9.4.eng: There are those who might say

sn36.19:9.5.eng: that this is the highest pleasure and happiness that sentient beings experience.

sn36.19:9.6.eng: But I don’t grant them that.

sn36.19:9.8.pli: Atthānanda, etamhā sukhā aññaṃ sukhaṃ abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca.
sn36.19:9.8.eng: Because there is another pleasure that is finer than that.

sn36.19:10.1.pli: Katamañcānanda, etamhā sukhā aññaṃ sukhaṃ abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca?

sn36.19:10.2.pli: Idhānanda, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
sn36.19:10.2.eng: It’s when, with the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
sn36.19:10.2.comm: This validates Pañcakaṅga’s view that neutral feeling can be reckoned as a subtle kind of pleasure.

sn36.19:10.3.pli: Idaṃ kho, ānanda, etamhā sukhā aññaṃ sukhaṃ abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca.
sn36.19:10.3.eng: This is a pleasure that is finer than that.

sn36.19:10.4.eng: There are those who might say

sn36.19:10.5.eng: that this is the highest pleasure and happiness that sentient beings experience.

sn36.19:10.6.eng: But I don’t grant them that.

sn36.19:10.8.pli: Atthānanda, etamhā sukhā aññaṃ sukhaṃ abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca.
sn36.19:10.8.eng: Because there is another pleasure that is finer than that.

sn36.19:11.1.pli: Katamañcānanda, etamhā sukhā aññaṃ sukhaṃ abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca?

sn36.19:11.2.pli: Idhānanda, bhikkhu sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā, paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamā, nānattasaññānaṃ amanasikārā, ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
sn36.19:11.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant—going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity—aware that ‘space is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space.

sn36.19:11.3.pli: Idaṃ kho, ānanda, etamhā sukhā aññaṃ sukhaṃ abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca.
sn36.19:11.3.eng: This is a pleasure that is finer than that.

sn36.19:11.4.eng: There are those who might say

sn36.19:11.5.eng: that this is the highest pleasure and happiness that sentient beings experience.

sn36.19:11.6.eng: But I don’t grant them that.

sn36.19:11.8.pli: Atthānanda, etamhā sukhā aññaṃ sukhaṃ abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca.
sn36.19:11.8.eng: Because there is another pleasure that is finer than that.

sn36.19:12.1.pli: Katamañcānanda, etamhā sukhā aññaṃ sukhaṃ abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca?

sn36.19:12.2.pli: Idhānanda, bhikkhu sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma, ‘anantaṃ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
sn36.19:12.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite consciousness.

sn36.19:12.3.pli: Idaṃ kho, ānanda, etamhā sukhā aññaṃ sukhaṃ abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca.
sn36.19:12.3.eng: This is a pleasure that is finer than that.

sn36.19:12.4.eng: There are those who might say

sn36.19:12.5.eng: that this is the highest pleasure and happiness that sentient beings experience.

sn36.19:12.6.eng: But I don’t grant them that.

sn36.19:12.8.pli: Atthānanda, etamhā sukhā aññaṃ sukhaṃ abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca.
sn36.19:12.8.eng: Because there is another pleasure that is finer than that.

sn36.19:13.1.pli: Katamañcānanda, etamhā sukhā aññaṃ sukhaṃ abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca?

sn36.19:13.2.pli: Idhānanda, bhikkhu sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma, ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
sn36.19:13.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, enters and remains in the dimension of nothingness.

sn36.19:13.3.pli: Idaṃ kho, ānanda, etamhā sukhā aññaṃ sukhaṃ abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca.
sn36.19:13.3.eng: This is a pleasure that is finer than that.

sn36.19:13.4.eng: There are those who might say

sn36.19:13.5.eng: that this is the highest pleasure and happiness that sentient beings experience.

sn36.19:13.6.eng: But I don’t grant them that.

sn36.19:13.8.pli: Atthānanda, etamhā sukhā aññaṃ sukhaṃ abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca.
sn36.19:13.8.eng: Because there is another pleasure that is finer than that.

sn36.19:14.1.pli: Katamañcānanda, etamhā sukhā aññaṃ sukhaṃ abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca?

sn36.19:14.2.pli: Idhānanda, bhikkhu sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
sn36.19:14.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, enters and remains in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

sn36.19:14.3.pli: Idaṃ kho, ānanda, etamhā sukhā aññaṃ sukhaṃ abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca.
sn36.19:14.3.eng: This is a pleasure that is finer than that.

sn36.19:14.4.eng: There are those who might say

sn36.19:14.5.eng: that this is the highest pleasure and happiness that sentient beings experience.

sn36.19:14.6.eng: But I don’t grant them that.

sn36.19:14.8.pli: Atthānanda, etamhā sukhā aññaṃ sukhaṃ abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca.
sn36.19:14.8.eng: Because there is another pleasure that is finer than that.

sn36.19:15.1.pli: Katamañcānanda, etamhā sukhā aññaṃ sukhaṃ abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca?

sn36.19:15.2.pli: Idhānanda, bhikkhu sabbaso nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ upasampajja viharati.
sn36.19:15.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, enters and remains in the cessation of perception and feeling.

sn36.19:15.3.pli: Idaṃ kho, ānanda, etamhā sukhā aññaṃ sukhaṃ abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca.
sn36.19:15.3.eng: This is a pleasure that is finer than that.
sn36.19:15.3.comm: Since all feeling is conditioned, and what is conditioned is suffering, the cessation of feeling is reckoned as pleasurable.

sn36.19:16.1.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, ānanda, vijjati yaṃ aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṃ vadeyyuṃ:
sn36.19:16.1.eng: It’s possible that wanderers of other religions might say:

sn36.19:16.2.pli: ‘saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samaṇo gotamo āha, tañca sukhasmiṃ paññapeti.
sn36.19:16.2.eng: ‘The ascetic Gotama spoke of the cessation of perception and feeling, and he includes it in happiness.

sn36.19:16.4.pli: Evaṃvādino, ānanda, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evamassu vacanīyā:
sn36.19:16.4.eng: When wanderers of other religions say this, you should say to them:

sn36.19:16.5.pli: ‘na kho, āvuso, bhagavā sukhaññeva vedanaṃ sandhāya sukhasmiṃ paññapeti.
sn36.19:16.5.eng: ‘Reverends, when the Buddha describes what’s included in happiness, he’s not just referring to pleasant feeling.

sn36.19:16.6.pli: Yattha yattha, āvuso, sukhaṃ upalabbhati, yahiṃ yahiṃ, taṃ taṃ tathāgato sukhasmiṃ paññapetī’”ti.
sn36.19:16.6.eng: The Realized One describes pleasure as included in happiness wherever it is found, and in whatever context.’”

sn36.2:1.3.pli: Sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā—

sn36.2:3.2.comm: Mosadhamma means “deceptive”; the commentary’s “perishable” is untenable.

sn36.2:3.3.eng: one sees them vanish <j>as they’re experienced again and again:

sn36.2:3.4.eng: that’s how to be free of desire for them.”

sn36.20:1.1.pli: “Dvepi mayā, bhikkhave, vedanā vuttā pariyāyena, tissopi mayā vedanā vuttā pariyāyena, pañcapi mayā vedanā vuttā pariyāyena, chapi mayā vedanā vuttā pariyāyena, aṭṭhārasāpi mayā vedanā vuttā pariyāyena, chattiṃsāpi mayā vedanā vuttā pariyāyena, aṭṭhasatampi mayā vedanā vuttā pariyāyena.
sn36.20:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, in one explanation I’ve spoken of two feelings. In another explanation I’ve spoken of three feelings, or five, six, eighteen, thirty-six, or a hundred and eight feelings.

sn36.20:1.2.eng: I’ve taught the Dhamma with all these explanations.

sn36.20:1.3.pli: Evaṃ pariyāyadesite kho, bhikkhave, mayā dhamme ye aññamaññassa subhāsitaṃ sulapitaṃ na samanumaññissanti, na samanujānissanti, na samanumodissanti, tesaṃ etaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ—bhaṇḍanajātā kalahajātā vivādāpannā aññamaññaṃ mukhasattīhi vitudantā viharissantīti.
sn36.20:1.3.eng: This being so, you can expect that those who don’t concede, approve, or agree with what has been well spoken will fight, quarrel, and dispute, continually wounding each other with barbed words.

sn36.20:1.4.eng: I’ve taught the Dhamma with all these explanations.

sn36.20:1.5.pli: Evaṃ pariyāyadesite kho, bhikkhave, mayā dhamme ye aññamaññassa subhāsitaṃ sulapitaṃ samanumaññissanti samanujānissanti samanumodissanti, tesaṃ etaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ—samaggā sammodamānā avivadamānā khīrodakībhūtā aññamaññaṃ piyacakkhūhi sampassantā viharissantīti.
sn36.20:1.5.eng: This being so, you can expect that those who do concede, approve, or agree with what has been well spoken will live in harmony, appreciating each other, without dispute, blending like milk and water, and regarding each other with kindly eyes.

sn36.20:2.1.eng: There are these five kinds of sensual stimulation. …

sn36.20:2.2.pli: ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, bhikkhave, vijjati yaṃ aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṃ vadeyyuṃ:
sn36.20:2.2.eng: It’s possible that wanderers of other religions might say:

sn36.20:2.3.pli: ‘saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samaṇo gotamo āha, tañca sukhasmiṃ paññapeti.
sn36.20:2.3.eng: ‘The ascetic Gotama spoke of the cessation of perception and feeling, and he includes it in happiness.

sn36.20:2.5.pli: Evaṃvādino, bhikkhave, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evamassu vacanīyā:
sn36.20:2.5.eng: Mendicants, when wanderers of other religions say this, you should say to them:

sn36.20:2.6.pli: ‘na kho, āvuso, bhagavā sukhaññeva vedanaṃ sandhāya sukhasmiṃ paññapeti.
sn36.20:2.6.eng: ‘Reverends, when the Buddha describes what’s included in happiness, he’s not just referring to pleasant feeling.

sn36.20:2.7.pli: Yattha yattha, āvuso, sukhaṃ upalabbhati yahiṃ yahiṃ, taṃ taṃ tathāgato sukhasmiṃ paññapetī’”ti.
sn36.20:2.7.eng: The Realized One describes pleasure as included in happiness wherever it is found, and in whatever context.’”

sn36.21:0.2.eng: 3. The Explanation of the Hundred and Eight

sn36.21:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
sn36.21:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

sn36.21:1.2.pli: Atha kho moḷiyasīvako paribbājako yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
sn36.21:1.2.eng: Then the wanderer Moḷiyasīvaka went up to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.
sn36.21:1.2.comm: Moḷiyasīvaka also appears in AN 6.47, where he also goes for refuge. His name means, “Tailor With a Topknot”.

sn36.21:1.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho moḷiyasīvako paribbājako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn36.21:1.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:

sn36.21:1.4.pli: “santi, bho gotama, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
sn36.21:1.4.eng: “Worthy Gotama, there are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:
sn36.21:1.4.comm: Sīvaka is referring to the Jains.

sn36.21:1.5.pli: ‘yaṃ kiñcāyaṃ purisapuggalo paṭisaṃvedeti sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā sabbaṃ taṃ pubbekatahetū’ti.
sn36.21:1.5.eng: ‘Everything this individual person experiences—pleasurable, painful, or neutral—is because of past deeds.’
sn36.21:1.5.comm: The view that all experiences are caused by past kamma is consistently rejected in the Suttas (eg. AN 3.61:2.1, MN 101:2.5. This is reflected in the later Theravada commentaries, which describe five interacting niyāmas, or systems of natural law: seasons (utu), genetics (bīja), moral or immoral deeds (kamma), mind (citta), and principles of the teaching (dhamma). Nonetheless, the view that all experiences are caused by kamma is extremely common among modern Buddhists, and is often heard even from learned scholars. This is a harmful misunderstanding, as it has led to discrimination against the poor and disabled in Buddhist countries. One point of confusion is that rebirth into a particular life is caused by kamma, so in that general sense, kamma is a necessary condition for having a life in which one can experience anything. But the feelings experienced in that life are caused by a variety of things, not necessarily by kamma. | Note the use of purisapuggala (“individual person”) as a Jain idiom. See MN 35:10.7 and note, and SN 22.22 and notes.

sn36.21:1.6.eng: What does the worthy Gotama say about this?”

sn36.21:2.1.eng: “Sīvaka, some feelings stem from bile disorders.
sn36.21:2.1.comm: “Bile” (pitta), “phlegm” (semha), and “wind” (vāta) are the three doṣa (“impairments”) of āyurveda (Suśruta Saṁhitā 1.15; Caraka Saṁhitā 1.12). When unbalanced they impair the proper homeostasis of bodily functioning. They are comparable to the four “humors” (fluids) of  old European medicine.

sn36.21:2.2.pli: Sāmampi kho etaṃ, sīvaka, veditabbaṃ yathā pittasamuṭṭhānānipi idhekaccāni vedayitāni uppajjanti.
sn36.21:2.2.eng: You can know this from your own personal experience,

sn36.21:2.3.pli: Lokassapi kho etaṃ, sīvaka, saccasammataṃ yathā pittasamuṭṭhānānipi idhekaccāni vedayitāni uppajjanti.
sn36.21:2.3.eng: and it is generally deemed to be true.

sn36.21:2.4.pli: Tatra, sīvaka, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
sn36.21:2.4.eng: Since this is so, the ascetics and brahmins whose view is that

sn36.21:2.5.pli: ‘yaṃ kiñcāyaṃ purisapuggalo paṭisaṃvedeti sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā sabbaṃ taṃ pubbekatahetū’ti.
sn36.21:2.5.eng: everything an individual person experiences is because of past deeds

sn36.21:2.6.pli: Yañca sāmaṃ ñātaṃ tañca atidhāvanti, yañca loke saccasammataṃ tañca atidhāvanti.
sn36.21:2.6.eng: go beyond personal experience and beyond what is generally deemed to be true.

sn36.21:2.7.eng: So those ascetics and brahmins are wrong, I say.

sn36.21:3.1.eng: Some feelings stem from phlegm disorders …

sn36.21:3.4.comm: As I write, global atmospheric CO2 is 428.29 ppm, and it has been 1.5℃ above average for three years. The grave health impacts of this “change in the weather” are attested in the CoP 30 Special Report by the World Health Organization: “climate change presents the most significant threat to human health of this century.”

sn36.21:3.5.comm: Parihāra is looking after or taking care, so visamaparihāra is “imbalanced self-care”.

sn36.21:3.6.comm: Such as ascetics who torment their bodies (MN 36:18.11).

sn36.21:3.7.pli: kammavipākajānipi kho, sīvaka, idhekaccāni vedayitāni uppajjanti.
sn36.21:3.7.eng: Some feelings are the result of past deeds.
sn36.21:3.7.comm: In all cases, past deeds are a necessary condition for the mere fact of having a body in which one can experience these feelings. Only in this final case, however, is a specific deed or deeds the cause of this specific feeling. Even then, the past deed is not a sufficient condition, as it can only be effective when other conditions are conducive. The technical term for this kind of condition is upanissaya (or its contraction upanisā; see SN 12.23:2.1): it is both necessary and closely supportive.

sn36.21:3.8.eng: You can know this from your own personal experience,

sn36.21:3.10.eng: and it is generally deemed to be true.
sn36.21:3.10.comm: “Generally deemed to be true” (lokassa saccasammataṁ), i.e. “common sense”.

sn36.21:3.12.pli: tatra, sīvaka, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
sn36.21:3.12.eng: Since this is so, the ascetics and brahmins whose view is that

sn36.21:3.13.pli: ‘yaṃ kiñcāyaṃ purisapuggalo paṭisaṃvedeti sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā sabbaṃ taṃ pubbekatahetū’ti.
sn36.21:3.13.eng: everything an individual person experiences is because of past deeds

sn36.21:3.14.pli: Yañca sāmaṃ ñātaṃ tañca atidhāvanti yañca loke saccasammataṃ tañca atidhāvanti.
sn36.21:3.14.eng: go beyond personal experience and beyond what is generally deemed to be true.

sn36.21:3.15.eng: So those ascetics and brahmins are wrong, I say.”

sn36.21:4.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, moḷiyasīvako paribbājako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn36.21:4.1.eng: When he said this, the wanderer Moḷiyasīvaka said to the Buddha,

sn36.21:4.3.pli: upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
sn36.21:4.3.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

sn36.21:5.3.eng: not taking care of yourself, overexertion,

sn36.21:5.4.eng: and the result of deeds is the eighth.”
